Hazards are environmental or situational threats. They apply ongoing damage, impose exhaustion, or force checks and saves until resolved. Hazards are not the same as conditions, but they can cause conditions.

Common hazards:

&reference[Burning]

&reference[Dehydration]

&reference[Falling]

&reference[Malnutrition]

&reference[Suffocation]

&reference[Sucking Ground]

&reference[Polluted Water]

Environmental effects are broad states of the world that apply to everyone in an area. They often come from weather, climate, altitude, or terrain.

  • Extreme Cold: Each hour, creatures without proper gear/resistance make a DC 10 Constitution save or gain a level of exhaustion.

  • Extreme Heat: Each hour in heat (often with heavy armor disadvantage), DC 5 + 1 per previous check Constitution save or take exhaustion.

  • Strong Wind: Disadvantage on ranged weapon attacks, Perception checks relying on hearing, and it can snuff out unprotected flames.

  • Heavy Precipitation: Rain or snow makes areas lightly obscured; heavy snowfall can count as heavily obscured and dampens fire.

  • Frigid Water: Each minute in icy water, DC 10 Constitution save or gain a level of exhaustion (resistance to cold grants advantage).

  • High Altitude: After 1 hour above 10,000 feet, DC 10 Constitution save each hour or suffer exhaustion until you acclimate.

Use these effects to set expectations for travel, weather, and exploration scenes.

While in a blizzard, creatures are affected by Extreme Cold, Heavy Precipitation, and Strong Wind.

  • All creatures in the area are &reference[Obscured] (Heavily).
Counts as Difficult Terrain.

Swimming in water more than 100 feet deep taxes creatures without a Swim Speed.

  • Constitution Save (DC 10, each hour): Creatures with a Swim Speed automatically succeed.

    • Failure: Gain 1 level of &reference[exhaustion].

    • Success: No effect.

• Counts as Difficult Terrain.

  • Creatures within are &reference[Obscured] (Lightly).

• Counts as Difficult Terrain.

  • If in a cave with exposed lava, creatures are under Extreme Heat. In open air, being within 20 feet also imposes Extreme Heat.

  • Damage:

    • Touched by Lava: [[/damage 3d10 fire]].

    • Submerged in Lava: [[/damage 10d10 fire]] at the start of each turn.

When the temperature is 0? F or lower, creatures exposed must save each hour.

  • Constitution Save (DC 10): Cold resistance or immunity auto-succeeds.

    • Failure: Gain 1 level of &reference[exhaustion].

    • Success: No effect.

At 100? F or higher without drinkable water, save each hour.

  • Constitution Save (DC 5, +5 per prior hour): Medium/Heavy armor has disadvantage. Fire resistance or immunity auto-succeeds.

    • Failure: Gain 1 level of &reference[exhaustion].

    • Success: No effect.

A creature can be immersed in frigid water for minutes equal to its Constitution score. Each additional minute requires a save.

  • Constitution Save (DC 10, each minute): Cold resistance/immunity or aquatic adaptation auto-succeeds.

    • Failure: Gain 1 level of &reference[exhaustion].

    • Success: No effect.
Everything within the area is &reference[Obscured] (Heavily).

• Area is &reference[Obscured] (Lightly); heavy snowfall may be &reference[Obscured] (Heavily).

  • Extinguishes open flames.

Traveling at 10,000+ feet counts each hour as 2 hours of pace.

  • Creatures can acclimate after 30 days.

  • No acclimation above 20,000 feet unless native.
Everything within the area is &reference[Obscured] (Lightly).
Counts as Difficult Terrain.

• Counts as Difficult Terrain.

  • Creatures who Dash must succeed on DC 10 Strength save or fall &reference[Prone].
Counts as Difficult Terrain.

Poisonous vapors (spores, gas, alchemical smoke).

  • Constitution Save (DC 10, every 1 minute):

    • Creatures that do not breathe are unaffected.

    • If you were poisoned by this effect within the last minute, you automatically fail.

    • Failure: You are &reference[Poisoned].

    • Success: No effect.

  • A strong gust of wind may disperse the fumes.

• Counts as Difficult Terrain.

  • Creatures with climbing gear or a Climb Speed ignore these effects.
Counts as Difficult Terrain.
Applies all effects of Strong Wind; creatures in the area are &reference[Obscured] (Lightly).
Counts as Difficult Terrain.

Counts as Difficult Terrain.

  • Dexterity Save (DC 10): Cold resistance/immunity or aquatic adaptation auto-succeeds.

    • Failure: Creature falls &reference[Prone].

    • Success: No effect.

• Disadvantage on ranged weapon attacks.

  • Extinguishes open flames and disperses fog.

  • Flying creatures must land at end of turn or fall.

Supports only 3d10 ? 10 pounds per 10-foot square. Exceeding weight breaks the ice; creatures fall into frigid water.

  • While on thin ice, also under effects of Slippery Ice.

• Counts as Difficult Terrain.

  • Moving through costs double speed and deals [[/damage 1 piercing]] per 5 feet moved.

  • Taking the Disengage action avoids this damage.

Applies Strong Wind and Heavy Precipitation; the GM may call down lightning bolts.

Thunderstorm Bolt

  • 5 ft. Radius ? Dexterity Save:

    • Failure: [[/damage 4d10 lightning]]; unattended flammables ignite.

    • Success: Half damage.

  • 50 ft. Radius ? 1 round ? Constitution Save:

    • Failure: &reference[Blinded] and &reference[Deafened].

    • Success: No effect.

Thunderstorm bolts can be heard and lightning seen from many miles away.

Hazards:

A burning creature or object takes [[/damage 1d8 fire]] at the end of its turn (or end of the round if it has no turn). Some sources may deal more than 1d8.

  • Action - Self: Extinguish the fire and become &reference[Prone].

  • The fire goes out if doused, submerged, or suffocated.

A creature requires water each day based on size. If it drinks less than half the requirement, it gains 1 level of &reference[exhaustion] at day's end. &reference[exhaustion] from dehydration cannot be removed until the creature drinks its full daily need.

This hazard may also represent extreme heat, alcohol, or magic when not tracking daily supplies.

A creature that falls takes [[/damage 1d6 bludgeoning]] per 10 feet (max 20d6) and is &reference[Prone] unless it takes no damage. Purposeful jumps of 10 ft. or less deal no damage.

  • Reaction - Grab: If a ledge is within reach, Athletics or Acrobatics DC 10, +1 DC per previous 10 ft. fallen. Success: stop falling and take damage only for distance fallen. Failure: keep falling (one attempt per turn).

  • Hazardous surfaces may add extra damage.

A creature needs food each day based on size. If it eats less than half, it must make a DC 10 Constitution save at day's end (creatures that do not eat are immune; at 5 or more days with no food, the save automatically fails).

  • Failure: Gain 1 level of &reference[exhaustion].

  • Success: No effect.

This hazard can also represent imprisonment, disasters, or magic when not tracking daily supplies.

Unsafe water can sicken those who drink or swim in it.

  • Constitution Save (DC 10, 1 hour):

    • Failure: &reference[Poisoned] (or another effect if the water is especially toxic or diseased).

    • Success: No effect.

  • DC, duration, and effects can vary with the contaminant.

Loose or unstable terrain (quicksand, sucking mud, bogs) can trap creatures.

  • On entry: Athletics or Acrobatics DC 10.

  • Failure: &reference[Restrained]. At the end of each of the creature's turns, DC increases by 5. After two turns restrained this way, the creature begins &reference[Suffocation].

  • Action: The creature or an ally (Athletics only) can attempt the check to escape.

  • Success: Escape the sucking ground.

A creature can hold its breath for 1 + Constitution modifier minutes (minimum 30 seconds). When that time expires, it suffocates.

  • At the end of each of its turns while suffocating, it gains 1 level of &reference[exhaustion].

  • When breathing resumes, remove all &reference[exhaustion] gained from suffocation.
